labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

labels.name: phase2
labels.description: This issue to be considered later.

issues.title: Message acknowledgement
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
Do we really need that 'server MUST acknowledge'? As the client has no way to know if the server supports it or not, the only benefit it might save the client sending 4 packets (as it's supposed to retransmit up to 4 times).
Also, the idea of ACK might lead to a rather undesirable idea of 'NACK' so the server has some authority to prevent the host from using the address.

IMHO the client shall just send N (default = 3?) packets with X seconds (default: X = 1)  between.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: Cleanup -- already addressed in PR #6.

issues.title: Client Refresh Time - 85% of Valid? 3hours? Default Router Lifetime?
issues.author: wkumari
issues.body:
> -It is RECOMMENDED that clients initiate a refresh at about 85% of the valid-lifetime.  Because RAs may periodically 'reset' the valid- lifetime, the refresh timer MUST be independently maintained from the address valid-lifetime.  Clients SHOULD set a refresh timer to 85% of the valid-lifetime when they complete a registration operation and only update this timer if 85% of any updated valid-lifetime would be sooner than the timer.
> +{TODO: is the preferred lifetime a good idea? The default value is 7 days which seems rather long. Indeed we might say that it's an administrator's job to configure non-default lifetime... Also,  what about statically assigned addresses or PIOs with the inifinite lifetime??}
>
> So, I think that the desire is that the client does this somewhat as a "keep-alive", so that the server knows when to remove it if the client cates on fire, or similar. I think that it should be 85% of the preferred lifetime, or N (4?) hours, whichever is less...
> Basically, if I connect to a WiFi in an airport, configure a SLAAC address for 6 months and then fly away, the DHCPv6 server should be able to purge me from the log / view the address as usable after some time much much less than 6 months :-)

Indeed. Having a timer is definitely a good idea, the question is: how
to calculate it? My point is that the valid lifetime is not really
suitable here, due to its default value of 1 month. The preferred
lifetime is a bit high as well. I'd say using a default router
lifetime as a starting point might be a good idea.

_Originally posted by @furry13 in https://github.com/wkumari/draft-wkumari-dhc-addr-notification/issues/1#issuecomment-1060056285_

comments.author: ekline
comments.body: The default router lifetime can legitimately be zero.  Even in these networks addr notification may be desired, so tying it dflt rtr lifetime doesn't seem right to me.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: I've added some comments / todo in the doc -- we could so some complex "minimum of <some number> and the maximum of the RA / default router lifetime / preferred lifetime" bit, but I suspect that is just over-engineering and we should instead choose some arbritary number -- the "failure" is that some number in 2^64 addresses are not used / the leases table gets full. Also, we need to add some text around not DoSing the lease table, but that is an existing issue....

issues.title: 1 Message per address vs all addresses in a single message
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
I see two ways:
- every time a host send a registration message it includes all addresses configured on the interface. 
Pros: allow explicit deprecations
Cons: allows an attacker to register an address even if it can't send pakcets from that address (by including it into the registration message)

- each message contains one address only - the address being registered.
 -- Pros: additional safety net: if the host can't send a packet from that address (e.g.SAVI) - it can't register the address.
 -- Cons: no explicit deprecation (but we can add another message for this, if needed)

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: We decided a long time ago to send the message from the address being registered so that L2 security could protect it.

issues.title: Having flags to indicate address properties
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
It might be useful to indicate address properties (e.g. stable vs temporary), so maybe we need a field to include this.
Smth like flags field?

comments.author: ekline
comments.body: IA_TA (temporary addrress) and IA_NA (non-temporary address) option types already include this 1-bit distinguishing information...

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: I'm unclear what the resolution here is. Anything needed to be done?

issues.title: Add mention of RFC 6939 - Client Link-Layer Address Option in DHCPv6
issues.author: wkumari
issues.body:
In Sec 5.1. (`DHCPv6 Address Registration Request`) I discuss the DUID and lack of local MAC.
Insert reference to "[RFC 6939 - Client Link-Layer Address Option in DHCPv6](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc6939/)". It seems that, based on the expected use and deployment cases we should just have this as a MUST, like:

> MUST include the DHCPv6 Client Link-Layer Address Option (RFC6393)


or similar.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: Closing. This was silly!

issues.title: support router originated registrations on behalf of clients?
issues.author: ekline
issues.body:
Question: should there be a mechanism to allow routers to generate registration messages for {L2,L3} pairs is has in its neighbor table?

Such a mechanism:

  * might reuse the same message type or use a new message type
  * would allow updated routers to contribute to debugging data while serving clients that don't support this option
  * might further overload a server on networks where client support for this behaviour is already robust
  * would need to tackle exactly what DUID should be generated by a router for these synthesized messages

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body:
This came up again in the wg. One of the issues was that the switch/relay can't really not know if the host is going to send an ADDR-REG-INFORM. If the switch/relay sends it, then the server might receive two messages for the same address from two different DUIDs. Also, the switch/relay probably won't know what options the client would put in the request - in particular, the FQDN option.

There seemed to be consensus in the room not to add anything to the draft for now.

issues.title: consider: mention on-link relays might do validation
issues.author: ekline
issues.body:
Since some vendor is going to do it anyway, better perhaps to mention the concept here to head off any stupid IPR filing.

The basic idea: if an on-link relay has knowledge of this message and access to neighbor table state it may perform some validation checks on the contents of the addr reg message.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: Any suggested text?

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body:
We already say this:

If a network is using FCFS SAVI [RFC6620], then the DHCPv6 server can trust that the ADDR-REG-INFORM message was sent by the legitimate owner of the address. This prevents a host from registering an address owned by another host.

Do we need more text? Any suggestions?

comments.author: ekline
comments.body: Perfetto

issues.title: Conflicting sentences re: refresh
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
Section 5.2:
"It is RECOMMENDED that clients initiate a refresh at about 85% of the preferred lifetime. "

Section 5.3:
"The client MUST refresh the registration when 1/3 of the Preferred Lifetime of the address has elapsed. Such retransmissions should be jittered."

issues.title: Suggestion: If the Server sends an ACK, then the client can stop transmitting.
issues.author: wkumari
issues.body:
"It should be noted that ADDR-REG-NOTIFICATION is the first and the only DHCPv6 message which does not require any form of acknowledgement from the server, so the retransmission logic described in Section 15 of RFC8415 is not really applicable."

Perhaps add: If the client *does* receive an acknowledgement, it should stop sending ... something.

From minutes: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-115-dhc-202211081630/

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
From minutes: [Ryan Globus] a boolean from the server might be helpful,
optional not required, as an ack

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: /we need to make it clear that the acknowledgment is **only** that the server has received the message. It is **not** permission to use the address or not -- this is just "yes, I heard you", not "yes, I agree"

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
I assume we need to use REPLY message for this?
In that case we might need to update RFC8415, as it says:
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8415.html#section-7.3

REPLY (7)                 A server sends a Reply message containing
                             assigned leases and configuration
                             parameters in response to a Solicit,
                             Request, Renew, or Rebind message received
                             from a client.  A server sends a Reply
                             message containing configuration parameters
                             in response to an Information-request
                             message.  A server sends a Reply message in
                             response to a Confirm message confirming or
                             denying that the addresses assigned to the
                             client are appropriate to the link to which
                             the client is connected.  A server sends a
                             Reply message to acknowledge receipt of a
                             Release or Decline message.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: https://github.com/wkumari/draft-wkumari-dhc-addr-notification/commit/d7ac3fbaa18d7eda6a88c0a0b5f8a5b7f813c101

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
It *feels* like this might fall under the spirit of "A server sends a Reply message to acknowledge receipt of a
Release or Decline message." It feels like this is conceptually similar to "acknowledge receipt"....

Closing for now, we can re-open if people are unhappy.

Thank you, Jen!

issues.title: Suggestion: Is this only for endpoints, or can a relay device be helpful and send these on the client's behalf?
issues.author: wkumari
issues.body: If we do this, just like for the serve ACK, we need to clarify that this is **just** informational -- the switch is helpfully telling the server that a client is using an address, but it MUST NOT block the message from the client, it MUST NOT use this for access control, etc.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
This seems like it might be quite complex, as it will likely require devices to spoof the global address. I think better to skip it for now? 

Ack: Eric Vynke

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: It looks like a duplicate of https://github.com/wkumari/draft-wkumari-dhc-addr-notification/issues/9

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: Duplicate of #9 .

issues.title: Document behaviour of switches/relays that forward the message
issues.author: lcolitti
issues.body:
1. Document how relays forward the message. Though we already say:

DHCPv6 relay agents that relay address registration messages directly from clients SHOULD include the client's link-layer address in the relayed message using the Client Link-Layer Address option ([RFC6939])


2. Ensure that switches and relays do not do anything special (e.g., update DHCPv6 binding tables) when they see a REPLY..

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body:
2 points essentially:

- SAVI enabled switches / switches doing DHCPv6 inspection and possibly adding e.g. Option 82 to packets passing through MAY perform this action on ADDR-REG-INFORM packets.

- same devices MUST NOT perform any action upon inspecting a pass-through REPLY for an ADDR-REG-INFORM. In general, the devices will (a) only inspect multicast packets anyway (which this would not be?) and (b) won't act on unknown messages in REPLY, but this should be explicit.

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: SGTM. To the second stipulation seems best worded as "In particular, they MUST NOT install any forwarding state based on the REPLY message."

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body: Forwarding state or filtering state (latter on SAVI switches)

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
>SAVI enabled switches / switches doing DHCPv6 inspection and possibly adding e.g. Option 82 to packets passing through MAY perform this action on ADDR-REG-INFORM packets.


Option82 is OPTION_SOL_MAX_RT - could you pls elaborate on this comment?

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: The second part addressed by https://github.com/wkumari/draft-wkumari-dhc-addr-notification/commit/6f13d9fc3d32e4d6274f5519a96bc198c8678ff1

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body: Ah crap sorry option 82 is DHCPv4. I don't actually know if any switches do this with DHCPv6. If they do, it's probably option 35.

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body:
Isn't this built in to DHCPv6? The relay-forward message contains the client link address.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8415#section-9.1

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body: Except option 35 was removed; I think it's just the relay agent ID now (53)

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body:
> Isn't this built in to DHCPv6? The relay-forward message contains the client link address.

Option 82 in DHCPv4 has the switch's port name/number, not the client LL. Now that I think about it I have no idea how (if at all) this is done in DHCPv6. I think the switch just behaves as a normal relay.

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: How about #40 ?

comments.author: eqvinox
comments.body:
> Except option 35 was removed; I think it's just the relay agent ID now (53)

AFAICS it's options 18 (required) and 37 (optional) that switches insert… and this took way longer to find than I'm willing to admit :disappointed: … the behavior is described in [RFC6221](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6221) aka LDRA. Unlike DHCPv4, where Option 82 is just inserted mid-packet, for DHCPv6 the switch does the full `RELAY-FORWARD` wrapping.

I guess since they're actual relays, switches don't need special distinction from relays (sorry for that confusion :face_with_spiral_eyes:), and it's just normal relay processing.

issues.title: Say that the administrator SHOULD be able to enable/disable ADDR-REG-INFORM
issues.author: lcolitti

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: Fixed by d4252ba.

issues.title: Define the format of the reply message
issues.author: lcolitti
issues.body:
The draft currently says nothing beyond the server should send a REPLY. It should say what the reply looks like. Possible options:

1. Empty REPLY message with just a transaction ID and nothing else.
2. REPLY message with a transaction ID and an IA Address option. Risks breaking existing relays.
3. New ADDR-REG-REPLY message that contains the IA Address.

Option #3 seems best (there are lots of xxx_REPLY message types already), except that the message code is only an 8-bit field.

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: Picking option 3 would simplify the second part of #35.

issues.title: Clarify "address appropriate for the host"
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's comment:

"> > "the address is not appropriate for the link;"
> We agreed that this would include DHCPv6-PD for the host, but it might be
> good to say so explicitely."

issues.title: Clarify that ULAs are of global scope and shall be registered
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Michael's comments to -00:

> > The client MUST only send the ADDR-REG-INFORM message for valid ([RFC4862])
> > addresses of global scope ([RFC4007]). The client MUST NOT send the
> > ADDR-REG-INFORM message for addresses configured by DHCPv6.
>
> RFC4007 predates ULA, so it isn't very clear to non-wizards if ULAs can be
> registered. I think they can, but others may not understand.

We can add the text. Actually this mechanism provides some useful side-effect: it might help detecting. rogue RAs (like a host sending RAs wit ULAs)

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: The text has been updated

issues.title: Brian Carpenter's comment re: DHCPv6 addresses
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
""The client MUST NOT send the ADDR-REG-INFORM message for addresses configured by DHCPv6."

Fair enough, but since this is a possible buggy behaviour, I think you need to specify what the server should do if it receives such a message - discard, or discard and log?"

1. IMHO the server should discard and MAY log
2. do we want to clarify the difference between DHCPv6 and DHCPv6-PD? Can a host register an address from a delegated prefix?

issues.title: Bernie's comments on -05
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
1. Clean up  OPTION_ADDR_REG_ENABLE and OPTION_ADDR_REG (& ADDR_REG_ENABLE) 
2. Add more text in section 4.4 (Signalling) about "inconsistent servers support" - when some servers do not (yet) support the mechanism

issues.title: Update security consideration re: passive attack
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From the email thread:

> Are we introducing a privacy concern by using multicast?
> If any server can effective turn on this reporting, and get all the hosts to
> multicast this info, have we just created a new passive discovery attack?

First of all, the vast majority of switches out there do not have MLD snooping enabled. So your passive discovery attack is possible already because of DAD (we discussed exactly that in the Security Consideration section of RFC9131). If the network has MLD snooping enabled - then an attacker can join 'all routers' group and still see GRAND (RFC9131) packets as well. If the attacker joins 'all DHCP servers' group and sees all DHCP traffic from the client, in which case all DHCP addresses are revealed anyway.IMHO if the network administrator wishes to hide addresses used by other clients, the network shall provide complete p2p isolation.

issues.title: What to do with static addresses?
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: - They would have infinite lifetime?

pulls.title: More details on the client behaviour
pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
- Specifying that there SHOULD be a message per address;
- Addresses MUST be preferred
- Messages SHOULD be sent from the address registered
- Some comments on refreshing logic

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
On Sun, Mar 6, 2022, 1:24 AM Warren Kumari ***@***.***> wrote:
> +The host SHOULD send the packet from the address being registered.
>
> Oooh! Yes... In my mental model it would, but I did't realize that this wasn't stated.

>  The end-host MUST include a Client Identifier option and at least one IA Address option in the ADDR-REG-NOTIFICATION message.
> +The host SHOULD send separate messages for each address (so each message include only one IA Address option) but MAY send a single packet containing multiple options.
> +
>
> I'll incorporate this, but why is this better than SHOULD send one packet with all of them, but MAY send separate ones?

 It's related to "the host SHOULD send a packet from the address being
registered" requirement. Sending the registration packet from the
address being registred ensures that only addresses the host can use
for communication are registered. As a result, if the infrastructure
has SABI (or smth similar) enabled, it's less likely that a host B
would register an address belonging to host A.
So if multiple addresses in the same registration message are allowed,
only one of them can be used as the source address - so there is no
guarantee that other addresses in the message can be used for sending
packets..

> -It is RECOMMENDED that clients initiate a refresh at about 85% of the valid-lifetime.  Because RAs may periodically 'reset' the valid- lifetime, the refresh timer MUST be independently maintained from the address valid-lifetime.  Clients SHOULD set a refresh timer to 85% of the valid-lifetime when they complete a registration operation and only update this timer if 85% of any updated valid-lifetime would be sooner than the timer.
> +{TODO: is the preferred lifetime a good idea? The default value is 7 days which seems rather long. Indeed we might say that it's an administrator's job to configure non-default lifetime... Also,  what about statically assigned addresses or PIOs with the inifinite lifetime??}
>
> So, I think that the desire is that the client does this somewhat as a "keep-alive", so that the server knows when to remove it if the client cates on fire, or similar. I think that it should be 85% of the preferred lifetime, or N (4?) hours, whichever is less...
> Basically, if I connect to a WiFi in an airport, configure a SLAAC address for 6 months and then fly away, the DHCPv6 server should be able to purge me from the log / view the address as usable after some time much much less than 6 months :-)

Indeed. Having a timer is definitely a good idea, the question is: how
to calculate it? My point is that the valid lifetime is not really
suitable here, due to its default value of 1 month. The preferred
lifetime is a bit high as well. I'd say using a default router
lifetime as a starting point might be a good idea.

reviews.author: wkumari
reviews.body:
Thank you.

Merging changes, also have comments to explain my thoughts.

W

comments.body: Oooh! Yes... In my mental model it would, but I did't realize that this wasn't stated.
I'll incorporate this, but why is this better than SHOULD send one packet with all of them, but MAY send separate ones?

So, I think that the desire is that the client does this somewhat as a "keep-alive", so that the server knows when to remove it if the client cates on fire, or similar. I think that it should be 85% of the preferred lifetime, or N (4?) hours, whichever is less... 

Basically, if I connect to a WiFi in an airport, configure a SLAAC address for 6 months and then fly away, the DHCPv6 server should be able to purge me from the log / view the address as usable after some time much much less than 6 months :-)

pulls.title: Adjust the retrans text to address Jen's Issue #19
pulls.author: wkumari
pulls.body: Addresses #19

comments.body:
I'm not sure it should be related to ND timers (also, Retransmit Timer can easily be set to zero).  Should we use Bernie's suggestion for  the standard retransmission logic (as per Section 15 of RFC8415)? Smth like:
"Registrations SHOULD be retransmitted according to the retransmission logic described in  Section 15 of RFC8415, using the following values:

IRT     REG_TIMEOUT
      MRT     0
      MRC     REG_MAX_RC
      MRD     0,

Default values: REG_TIMEOUT = 1 sec, REG_MAX_RC = 4"
Is there any reason to do it at 1/3 and not on 85%? Also, where 4 hrs are coming from? Random number?

Actually, I don't think that that is right. The text in RFC8415 is to address something like "I sent a packet and didn't get a reply, so I should retransmit this (and at a fairly high rate (order of seconds)) until someone replies".  This is similar to e.g TCP retransmission. 

What this is trying to say is something more like a keepalive / refresh. I send a "Hey, I'm using this address..." (and don't necessarily get a reply), and then a fairly long time later I send "Hey, I'm using that this address..."

```suggestion
To reduce the effects of packet loss on registration, the client SHOULD retransmit initial registrations.Registrations SHOULD be retransmitted according to the retransmission logic described in Section 15 of RFC8415, using the following values:

*     IRT REG_TIMEOUT
*     MRT  0
*     MRC  REG_MAX_RC
*     MRD  0.

The default values for new configuration variables are listed below:

*    REG_TIMEOUT = 1 sec;
*   REG_MAX_RC = 4.

```

I was thinking that if one is on a lossy network, and one wants to keep "refreshing" an entry, something like what most protocols do it the right thing -- e.g BGP sends 3 keepalives before the session dies. 
And, yes, 4 hours is a random number - these are for IPv6 addresses, and there are likely lots of available on a link, so we don't need a very short timeout (we don't need to reap them too quickly), but also having some sort of "hey, I'm still here" message seems useful.... so, something between 1 minute and 1 year, and 4 hours "sounded right" :-)

```suggestion
To reduce the effects of packet loss on registration, the client SHOULD send initial registrations ADDREG_MAX_RT times. The minimal interval between retransmissions MUST be at least ADDREG_RT_DELAY second and should be jittered to prevent overloading the DHCP infrastructure when a new prefix is announced to the link via Router Advertisement. It should be noted that ADDR-REG-NOTIFICATION is the first and the only DHCPv6 message which does not require any form of acknowledgement from the server, so   the retransmission logic described in Section 15 of RFC8415 is not really applicable.
The default values for the variables:

*      ADDREG_MAX_RT  2
*     ADDREG_RT_DELAY 3 secs

The client SHOULD allow those variables to be configured by the administrator.
```

```suggestion
The client MUST refresh the registration every AddrRegRefresh seconds, where  AddrRegRefresh  is min(1/3 of the Preferred Lifetime filed in the PIO; 4 hours ). Registration refresh packets SHOULD be retransmitted using the same logic as described in the 'Retransmission' section below. In particular, retransmissions SHOULD be jittered to avoid synchronization causing a large number of registrations to expire at the same time.
```

pulls.title: Adopted version: mostly Jim Reid's comments
pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
Addressing Jim Reid' comments:

- Rephrasing the sentence about lack of parity impeding enterprise IPv6 deployment.
- Renaming section 3 to registration mechanism overview
- Replace "end host" etc with "client"
- Explicitly specifying that the host MUST ignore REPLYs if the reply doesn't contain IA Address for the address configured on the host.

Also:
-  explictly describing the use of transaction-id
-  moving the text around to have the mechanism overview first, and then the details.

pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
Addressing Jim Reid' comments:

Rephrasing the sentence about lack of parity impeding enterprise IPv6 deployment. Renaming section 3 to registration mechanism overview Replace "end host" etc with "client"
Explicitly specifying that the host MUST ignore REPLYs if the reply doesn't contain IA Address for the address configured on the host. Also:

explictly describing the use of transaction-id
moving the text around to have the mechanism overview first, and then the details.

workflow tooling happy.

```suggestion
The DHCPv6 IA Address option {{!RFC8415}} is used to specify the address to be registered.
```

I see you deleted the text that says the destination address of the ADDR-REG-REPLY is the address being registered. Is that intentional? If not, maybe we can put it back, and make this text say:
- The IPv6 destination address does not match the address being registered
- The IA-Address option does not match the address being registered
- The address being registered is not assigned to the interface receiving the message.
"if the host" should be "if the client

```suggestion
To comply with section 16.1 of [RFC8415], the client MUST leave the transaction ID unchanged in retransmissions of an ADDR-REG-INFORM message.
```

```suggestion
The client MUST only send the packet on the network interface that has the address being registered (i.e. if the client has multiple interfaces with different addresses, it should only send the packet on the interface with the address being registered).
```

I did not delete that text, it's moved to DHCPv6 Address Registration Acknowledgement. 
Thanks for proposing the text, I'll  update this section.
I've updated the text

pulls.title: Don't forbid sending addr-reg option if M=O=0
pulls.author: lcolitti
pulls.body:
This may be useful in the future to inform the network of the device's hostname on networks that don't have DHCPv4 or DHCPv6 servers.

On such networks, setting M=1 or O=1 might confuse clients by making them think that there is a DHCPv6 server. Those clients might, for example, refuse to connect to the network, or time out, if their DHCPv6 requests do not receive a response.

comments.author: lcolitti
comments.body: Addressed minor comments and merging these changes. Leaving PR open to address the remaining review comment.

Might want to say "changes" instead of "updates". Rationale: if the lifetime is currently 597, and we receive an RA with a lifetime of 597, that might be construed as an "update".

Further, we might want to say something like, "changes the Valid Lifetime of an existing address by more than 5%" or "by more than 1 minute" or something like that.

That ensures that if the RAs are slightly desynchronized with the client time, the client does not run this code every time. An example of how this might happen is:
- Server sends an RA with a lifetime of 600, but it is delayed by 300ms by congestion.
- After 60 seconds, server sends an RA with a lifetime of 540, which is not delayed by congestion. At this point the client will think the lifetime is still 541 seconds, and thus it might think that the lifetime "changed".
Maybe 5% and 1 minute are too high, but you get the idea. We could say "by 1% (to avoid rescheduling due to clock skew or transmission delays)". No need to do that in this PR though.
"no update needs to be sent" -> "no refresh needs to be sent"
Addressed by fixup commit.

pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
0. Fixing inconsistent option name
1. Addressing IANA comments (adding option attributes).
2. Clarifying inconsistent replies from servers
3. Allowing the server to accept registration from delegated prefixes.

pulls.title: Avoid flapping if some servers support registration and some don't.
pulls.author: lcolitti
pulls.body:
Instead, always register if at least one server returns the OPTION_ADDR_REG_ENABLE option, and say the client MUST stop registering if that server stops returning the option.

As a side effect, this text no longer forbids signalling support for address registration in other ways, e.g., via an RA option.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body: This seems fine / good to me, but Lorenzo's review was requested, so this is just a note...
Actually it's still possible for the client to receive no reply. For example, the server might be temporarily unreachable, or packet loss might cause all the ADDR-REG_REQUEST packets to be dropped.

pulls.title: New address registration algorithm
pulls.author: lcolitti
pulls.body:
This algorithm is more efficient than what is currently in the draft, because it does not refresh the registration on the first RA after the refresh.

It's also simpler than the various versions we've been thinking of lately.

comments.body: ...any furture/subsequent refreshes?
s/If the network never changes the lifetime, or stops refreshing the lifetime/If the client stops receiving RAs refreshing the lifetime/ maybe..

Is the jitter fixed per client/per PIO? Otherwise we have a slight problem:

In theory,  as long as the network sends RAs with the same lifetime, the first RA creates an address, the second schedule a refresh, and all subsequent RAs do nothing until NextAddrRegRefreshTime comes (as min(now + AddrRegRefreshInterval, NextAddrRegRefreshTime) wouldn't change). However if you apply *dfferent* jitter every time when AddrRegRefreshInterval() is calculated, the client will be rescheduling the refresh there abd back again on *every* RA.
Changed to be fixed per-client.
Well, something that is scheduled generally *has* to be in the future... :-)

pulls.title: Force refeshes to occur periodically.
pulls.author: lcolitti
pulls.body:
This guarantees that refreshes occur every four hours, regardless of the address's lifetime.

It's not clear whether this is an improvement, though - the network operator can already force refreshes to occur every 4 hours, by setting the address lifetime to 4 hours.

It might be simpler to instead get rid of the 4-hour minimum and just add text to point out that the operator can control the address refresh frequency by setting the RA lifetime. If we do this, we need to do something about static addresses.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: We decided not to do this

pulls.title: Get rid of the 4-hour minimum.
pulls.author: lcolitti
pulls.body:
This didn't really make sense because it did not guarantee that refreshes were sent every 4 hours. Just remove it, and instead, note in the text that the network administrator can control the frequency of refreshes by setting the PIO lifetime appropriately.

Retain the 4-hour value for static addresses, but say that it SHOULD be configurable.
